sub_topic: Calculation of the polarization in an electrochemical cell
message_1: What is the net polarization observed in an electrochemical cell containing a zinc metal electrode and a copper metal electrode when both electrodes are placed in a solution of copper sulfate? Given that the zinc electrode has a surface area of 5 cm² and the copper electrode has a surface area of 8 cm². The concentration of copper sulfate solution is 0.1 M and the cell potential is measured to be 0.55 V. (Assume all other parameters are at standard conditions). Calculate the polarization of the cell.
message_2:
To calculate the polarization of the cell, we need to first determine the standard cell potential (E°) for the given electrochemical cell and then compare it with the measured cell potential (E_cell).

The given electrochemical cell can be represented as:

Zn(s) | Zn²⁺(aq) || Cu²⁺(aq) | Cu(s)

The standard reduction potentials (E°) for the half-reactions are:

Zn²⁺(aq) + 2e⁻ → Zn(s)  E° = -0.76 V
Cu²⁺(aq) + 2e⁻ → Cu(s)  E° = +0.34 V

The overall cell reaction is:

Zn(s) + Cu²⁺(aq) → Zn²⁺(aq) + Cu(s)

The standard cell potential (E°) for the cell is the difference between the standard reduction potentials of the two half-reactions:

E° = E°(Cu²⁺/Cu) - E°(Zn²⁺/Zn) = 0.34 V - (-0.76 V) = 1.10 V

Now, we have the standard cell potential (E°) and the measured cell potential (E_cell):

E° = 1.10 V
E_cell = 0.55 V

The polarization (P) of the cell is the difference between the standard cell potential and the measured cell potential:

P = E° - E_cell = 1.10 V - 0.55 V = 0.55 V

The net polarization observed in the electrochemical cell is 0.55 V.
